post_text: Dodge County Schools have been awarded a grant to receive 27 WiFi Rangers for our students for the 20-21 school year! In a press release from Governor Kemp’s office this summer, “More than 22 percent of rural Americans do not have access to high-speed internet, compared to 1.5 percent of urban dwellers without high-speed internet. This means that rural students are almost 15 times more likely to lack access to the internet for remote learning when school buildings are closed.” DCSS will choose multiple locations for Wi-Fi Ranger networks, installing them in unserved areas where students do not have access to the internet at home throughout all of our communities within Dodge County. Once it is installed at a location, students can access the internet from the parking lot of the locations such as a city hall building or church. More information regarding locations and accessibility will be released soon. Thanks to our Technology Director, Rick Rogers, for obtaining this grant for all of our kids!

As this week comes to an end, I want to thank each and every teacher we have in this system. YOU are our rock. YOU are what keeps this ship floating. I am blessed to be able to work with each and every one of you and can't wait for the day that we can all be together again!

Mariella Douglas

Dodge County Hospital
April 20 at 4:47 AM ·

Today started another week. We have had as many as 13 on isolation at one time over the last two weeks. We are fortunate to have all the masks and gowns and gloves and hats that we need. We miss our staff that are sick and those who can’t work because their other job won’t let them come into our environment since we have positives-but we completely understand. The more people stay healthy the better for us! We celebrate Max going home and others returning. We have been so blessed by our community! Churches mainly but individuals also bringing us food as we quarantine daily at work. More than the food is the knowledge that we are loved. There have been some really heart wrenching stories as lives come and go during this time. It is stressful conditions for everyone. It takes each department to provide support and make it all come together smoothly. Praying for a good week and a flattened curve!

post_text: As many of you have heard, Gov. Kemp will be signing an executive order stating that all Georgia PK-12th grade schools will be closed for the remainder of the 2019-2020 school year. Although this mandate breaks our hearts, we understand that this is an unprecedented time that requires us all to do our civic duty to keep Georgia safe. We know that there are several questions and concerns about the closure, commencements, grading, and so much more. As we make difficult decisions and discuss possible solution with other surrounding districts, we will let everyone know. We have you all in our thoughts and prayers during this difficult time. The Dodge County School System asks for your patience as we find ways to sort through all of the details as quickly as possible. We do not know all the answers, but we will do the best we can for all of our 3000+ students and 400+ staff. Students, we miss you! We love you! Stay safe, wash your hands, and stay at home! ❤️
